title-group.article-title: Postdischarge opioid use after lumbar spine surgery among older adults in Ontario: a population-based cohort study

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Prescription opioid use places a considerable economic burden on health care systems. Older patients undergoing surgical procedures for painful conditions commonly receive opioids pre- and postoperatively, and are susceptible to adverse reactions. This study explores predictors of prolonged postoperative opioid use among older patients after lumbar spine surgery and the consequences in terms of health care utilization and costs.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: We conducted a retrospective population-based cohort study using Ontario administrative data from older adults undergoing spine surgery between 2006 and 2017. Data were analyzed from 90 days preoperatively to 1 year after hospital discharge, with last postoperative opioid prescriptions stratified into 90-day increments. We used multivariable ordinal logistic regression to identify predictors of long-term opioid use and generalized linear modelling to examine resource utilization and health care costs (2021 Canadian dollars).

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Of 15 109 patients included, 40.8% received preoperative opioid prescriptions. Preoperative opioid use strongly predicted prolonged postoperative use (odds ratio [OR] 4.47, 95% confidence interval [CI] 4.16–4.79), with 48.3% of patients who received preoperative opioids continuing to use opioids for longer than 9 months, relative to 12.7% of those without preoperative use. Several other risk factors for prolonged use were identified. Patients receiving long-term postoperative opioids incurred greater health care costs relative to those with opioids prescribed for fewer than 90 days (OR 1.49, 95% CI 1.44–1.54).

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Among older adults undergoing spine surgery, preoperative opioid use was a strong predictor of prolonged postoperative use, which was associated with increased health care costs. These results form an important baseline for future studies evaluating strategies to reduce opioid use targeting older surgical populations.

sec.title: Contexte:
sec.p: L’utilisation d’opioïdes vendus sur ordonnance impose un très lourd fardeau aux systèmes de santé. On les prescrit souvent en période pré- et postopératoire aux malades âgés qui subissent des interventions chirurgicales pour des maladies douloureuses et cela comporte des risques de réactions indésirables. Cette étude explore les prédicteurs d’une utilisation prolongée des opioïdes en période postopératoire chez des personnes âgées opérées à la colonne vertébrale et son impact sur l’utilisation des ressources sanitaires et les coûts associés.

sec.title: Méthodes:
sec.p: Nous avons procédé à une étude de cohorte populationnelle rétrospective à partir des données administratives de l’Ontario concernant les adultes âgés ayant subi une chirurgie de la colonne entre 2006 et 2017. Les données ont été analysées pour la période allant de 90 jours avant l’intervention à 1 an suivant le congé hospitalier, et les dernières ordonnances postopératoires d’opioïdes ont été stratifiées par tranches de 90 jours. Nous avons utilisé l’analyse de régression logistique multivariée ordinale pour identifier les prédicteurs d’une utilisation prolongée des opioïdes et un modèle linéaire généralisé pour examiner l’utilisation des ressources sanitaires et les coûts associés (dollars canadiens de 2021).

sec.title: Résultats:
sec.p: Parmi les 15 109 personnes incluses, 40,8 % avaient reçu une ordonnance d’opioïdes avant leur intervention. L’utilisation d’opioïdes en période préopératoire s’est révélé être un fort prédicteur d’utilisation postopératoire prolongée (rapport des cotes [RC] 4,47, intervalle de confiance [IC] de 95 % 4,16–4,79), et 48,3 % des malades ayant reçu des opioïdes en période préopératoire ont continué de les utiliser pendant plus de 9 mois, contre 12,7 % des malades qui n’en avaient pas pris. Plusieurs autres facteurs de risque d’utilisation prolongée ont été identifiés. Les malades qui ont reçu des opioïdes ont engendré des dépenses en soins de santé plus élevées que les malades à qui on en avait prescrit pour moins de 90 jours (RC 1,49, IC de 95 % 1,44–1,54).

sec.title: Conclusion :
sec.p: Chez les adultes âgés soumis à une chirurgie de la colonne, l’utilisation préopératoire d’opioïdes a été un fort prédicteur d’utilisation postopératoire prolongée, qui a été associée à une hausse des coûts de soins de santé. Ces résultats constituent une importante base de connaissances pour les futures études qui évalueront des stratégies de réduction du recours aux opioïdes à l’intention de la patientèle chirurgicale âgée.

body.p: Opioid use in North America has been declared a public health crisis, with Canada and the United States currently positioned as the 2 largest consumers of prescription opioids in the world.1 A total of 15 393 opioid-related deaths were reported in Canada between January 2016 and December 2019, with 11.8% of the Canadian population using prescribed opioid pain relievers in 2017.2 The opioid epidemic carries a considerable financial burden, contributing an estimated $438.6 million in total health care costs across Canada in 2017.2 Prescription opioids, often used to treat postsurgical pain, have been shown to be a factor in opioid-related complications and death.3–5 This emphasizes the importance of analyzing the risks and costs associated with long-term postsurgical opioid use.6,7

Preoperative opioid use has been identified, in some populations, as a risk factor for surgical complications, hospital readmission, increased postsurgical costs, worsened outcomes, and chronic opioid dependency (use exceeding 90 d postsurgery).3,8–18 However, in a large study of orthopedic patients undergoing hip and knee arthroplasty, preoperative opioid use did not predict prolonged postoperative prescriptions.19 In the setting of spine surgery, patients commonly receive preoperative opioids and remain on opioids for a prolonged period postoperatively.11,14,20–27 Owing to a high frequency of opioid-related adverse reactions and the need for orthopedic surgery, older adults are particularly at risk from long-term opioid use.28–30

There is limited literature on postoperative prescribing practices among older patients and their relation to health care utilization and costs, including those in a publicly funded health care environment.3,9,19,31 Recently, strategies to reduce postoperative opioid use among older adults have been increasingly adopted.32,33 To establish a baseline for the future determination of the effectiveness of such strategies in reducing the duration of opioid use and associated health care costs in this population, the primary objectives of the current study were to explore predictors of long-term postoperative opioid use among patients aged 65 years and older after lumbar spine surgery, and to explore the relation between the duration of postoperative opioid use and health care resource utilization and cost among these patients. As the duration of opioid use among older adults after surgery is variable and may lead to adverse effects and increased costs, the questions addressed were as follows: what factors predict long-term postoperative opioid use among older adults after lumbar spine surgery, and how does postoperative opioid use affect health care costs and resource utilization in this population?

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: We conducted a population-based retrospective cohort study involving adults aged 65 years and older who underwent lumbar spine surgery in Ontario, Canada, between Apr. 1, 2006, and Mar. 31, 2017, with last follow-up until April 2018. Given that Ontario has publicly funded hospital care and physician services, we were able to access provincial data on all Ontario residents. Furthermore, the Ontario Drug Benefit (ODB) database includes all drug prescriptions for patients aged 65 years and older. This study was conducted from the payer’s (Ontario Ministry of Health) perspective. All costs were reported in 2021 Canadian dollars.

sec.title: Data sources
sec.p: We identified the study cohort using several linked population-based administrative databases available from ICES in Toronto, Ontario.34 ICES is an independent, nonprofit research institute whose legal status under Ontario’s health information privacy law allows it to collect and analyze health care and demographic data, without consent, for health system evaluation and improvement. Data from ODB were linked with the Canadian Institute for Health Information’s Discharge Abstract Database, the Ontario Health Insurance Plan (OHIP) data set, the Registered Persons Database, and the Ontario Cancer Registry (see Appendix 1, Table S1, available at www.canjsurg.ca/lookup/doi/10.1503/cjs.003723/tab-related-content, for database information). These data sets were linked using unique encoded identifiers and analyzed at ICES. Further details are accessible through the ICES website.34

Exclusion criteria consisted of any diagnosis of cancer or palliative care within 1 year before index admission or 1 year postdischarge, spinal infections (e.g., discitis and osteomyelitis) in the year before surgery, spinal fracture or malignancy within 30 days before the surgery index date, and patients with missing sex or age data. The date of first lumbar surgery was considered the index date.

Preoperative data included prescriptions filled for opioids and other medications within 90 days before surgery, age, sex, socioeconomic status (neighbourhood income quintile based on census data), residence in a long-term care facility, hospital type (teaching or community hospital), and comorbidities. The admission date was used as the start of the 90-day look-back window, and patients were followed for 1 year after discharge. For patients without a discharge date or admission date recorded, the date of surgery was used as the start date for both followup and look-back.

sec.title: Pre- and postoperative opioid utilization
sec.p: Patients were classified as having used preoperative opioids if there were outpatient opioid prescriptions filled during the 90 days before the index date. For patients with documented postdischarge opioid prescriptions, the duration of opioid use was classified using a 4-level ordinal scale, dependent on when patients obtained their latest opioid prescription: a) 1–90 days, b) 91–180 days, c) 181–270 days, and d) 271–365 days. Data related to patients for whom no records for postoperative opioid prescriptions were available were reported.

Opioids included immediate-release and long-acting morphine, oxycodone, hydrocodone, hydromorphone, meperidine, fentanyl, codeine, and tramadol, as well as combination opioids with acetaminophen or acetylsalicylic acid.35

sec.title: Outcomes — resource utilization and cost estimates
sec.p: Data associated with costs were linked with diagnostic and procedural information (Appendix 1, Table S1). We calculated the total aggregate 1-year health care cost per patient after index surgery using a costing methodology developed for Ontario health administrative data for the following 5 sectors: hospitalizations, continuing care, outpatient care, physician costs, and prescription medications.36 Specific costs included hospitalizations, ambulatory emergency department visits, same-day surgeries, physician services, laboratory services, nonphysician costs (e.g., physiotherapists and chiropractors), continuing care, long-term care, home care, and rehabilitation.

We estimated costs associated with physician visits and laboratory tests based on the claims history in the OHIP database. Costs related to short episodes of care (duration < 60 d), such as emergency visits, day procedures, and ambulatory clinics (including outpatient oncology and dialysis services), were obtained from the National Ambulatory Care Reporting System. We obtained costs and use of complex continuing care from the Continuing Care Reporting System, costs of home care from the Home Care Database, costs of inpatient mental health care from the Ontario Mental Health Reporting System, and costs of surgeries from the Same Day Surgery database.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: We used descriptive statistics to summarize baseline patient characteristics. Continuous variables were summarized using means, standard deviations, medians, interquartile ranges, and range (minimum and maximum values). We summarized categorical variables using frequency counts and percentages, with χ2 tests used to test for intergroup differences. We used multivariable ordinal logistic regression models to examine the profile of patients who used opioids for more than 271 days after surgery, assessing the association between surgery type and the duration of postoperative opioid use. Covariates included preoperative data as well as patient disposition after discharge. After regression, we calculated the maximum likelihood estimates and odds ratios (ORs) to evaluate the ability of each covariate to predict long-term postoperative use.

We used a generalized linear model with a log-link function and γ distribution to model health care resource costs. We applied a γ distribution to the data set because of the nonnegative and positively skewed distribution of costs.37 The log-link function provides an estimate of the proportional change in mean costs with increases in duration of opioid use. Owing to the restricted ability to apply the statistical findings of the log estimates, constructed on a log scale, the generated estimates were exponentiated to produce mean ratios that could then be converted to percent change values.38,39
We performed all analyses using SAS version 9.4 (SAS Institute), using a 2-tailed p value of less than 0.05 to define statistical significance.

sec.title: Ethics approval
sec.p: The Queen’s University Health Sciences Research Ethics Board approved this study.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The study sample included 15 109 patients, of which 59.0% were aged 65–74 years (n = 8912), 36.7% were aged 75–84 years (n = 5546), and 4.3% were aged 85 years and older (n = 651). Females made up 50.8% of the study population (n = 7673), with 99.5% of the entire cohort not living in long-term care at study onset (n = 15 029). Regarding surgery type, 78.5% of patients underwent posterior spinal decompression (n = 11 864), 16.6% posterior decompression and fusion (n = 2510), and 4.9% anterior decompression and fusion (n = 735). Preoperatively, 40.8% of patients had filled opioid prescriptions during the 90-day lookback window (n = 6165). Additional patient demographic information is presented in Table 1 and Appendix 1, Table S2.

sec.title: Predictors of long-term postoperative opioid use
sec.p: Patients’ last postoperative opioid prescriptions were filled in 57.7% (n = 8723) of the sample within 1–90 days, 6.8% (n = 1030) within 91–180 days, 8.2% (n = 1245) within 181–270 days, and 27.2% (n = 4111) within 271–365 days. Of patients receiving preoperative opioids, 48.3% (n = 2976) received postoperative opioid prescriptions within 271–365 days, relative to 12.7% (n = 1135) of those not using preoperative opioids. After adjustment for covariates, patients receiving preoperative opioid prescriptions were more likely to receive opioid prescriptions for 271–365 days after discharge, relative to patients with no preoperative opioid prescriptions (OR 4.47, 95% confidence interval [CI] 4.16–4.79) (Figure 1). Patients who required 1 repeat spine surgery in the year after index surgery were more likely to require long-term opioid treatment (adjusted OR 2.00, 95% CI 1.74–2.29). Compared with anterior decompression with fusion, posterior decompression and posterior decompression with fusion were associated with increased duration of opioid use (OR 1.33, 95% CI 1.14–1.56, and OR 1.37, 95% CI 1.16–1.60, respectively). Other significant factors associated with increased likelihood of postoperative opioid use within 271–365 days included younger age, female sex, lower socioeconomic status, discharge to an alternate level of care facility, more reported comorbidities, and preoperative use of benzodiazepines, calcium channel blockers, and tricyclic antidepressants (Table 2).

sec.title: Resource utilization and cost estimates
sec.p: During the 1-year follow-up period, the mean total costs were lowest among patients with 1–90 days of postoperative opioid use ($14 025, standard deviation [SD] $19 647), compared with those with 91–180 days ($26 479, SD $32 595; OR 1.41, 95% CI 1.34–1.48), 181–270 days ($26 384, SD $37 158; OR 1.44, 95% CI 1.37–1.51), and 271–365 days ($28 839, SD $36 768; OR 1.49, 95% CI 1.44–1.54) (Table 3 and Table 4). Patients for whom no data were available regarding postoperative opioid prescriptions incurred mean costs of $25 223 (SD $42 644). After adjustment for covariates, the duration of postoperative opioid utilization was significantly associated with increased health care costs, although preoperative opioid use in the 90-day look-back window was not significantly associated with increased postoperative health care costs, ($1670, SD $6553 v. $2127, SD $7462; OR 0.99, 95% CI 0.96–1.02) (Table 3 and Table 4). Additional cost information stratified by surgical procedure is presented in Appendix 1, Table S3.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Preoperative opioid use was a major predictor of long-term use postoperatively, with 48.3% of patients who received preoperative opioids continuing to fill opioid prescriptions more than 9 months after surgery, relative to 12.7% of those without preoperative use. Other predictive factors of long-term opioid use include repeat surgical procedures, younger age, and preoperative use of anxiolytics or tricyclic antidepressants. Mean total health care costs were lowest among patients who had used postoperative opioids for fewer than 90 days. The duration of postoperative opioid prescriptions was significantly associated with greater costs, although preoperative opioid prescriptions were not directly associated with total costs after surgery.

The association between preoperative opioid use and an increased likelihood of long-term postoperative opioid use aligns with some previous studies in spine surgery,10–14,18,40,41 although this association is not as consistent with other types of orthopedic surgery.30

Another significant predictor of long-term postoperative opioid use was preoperative use of benzodiazepines and tricyclic antidepressants. Previous literature has shown an increased prevalence of opioid use among individuals with mental health conditions.15,18,41 Though the use of benzodiazepines and tricyclic antidepressants does not directly indicate diagnoses of mental health conditions, the literature has demonstrated an existing link between the use of some mental health drugs and opioids. These drugs are sometimes used as adjuncts to analgesics in chronic pain conditions. Lo and colleagues suggest a neurobiological link between chronic pain and depression, though this trend was not observed across all medication types.25 Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), and antipsychotics were not found to be significantly associated with long-term postoperative opioid prescriptions, highlighting a need for further research examining possible links between mental health conditions and medications with prolonged opioid use postoperatively. Other factors that are significantly related to health care costs include surgery type, age group, number and type of comorbidities, discharge disposition, and residence in a long-term care facility. Patients with documented postoperative opioid use for fewer than 90 days used fewer health care resources and incurred lower costs than the other cohorts or patients for whom no opioid prescriptions were available. As ODB data capture only out-patient prescription information, patients with no documented outpatient opioid prescriptions may have been discharged to in-patient long-term care or rehabilitation facilities, explaining the greater health care resource utilization within the cohort with no documented opioid prescriptions postoperatively. The current study showed that preoperative opioid use was strongly predictive of long-term postoperative opioid prescriptions, although preoperative opioid prescriptions did not correlate with increased postoperative health care costs. These findings support a previous study of health care utilization and costs that found that patients who were dependent on opioids postoperatively incurred greater overall costs regardless of preoperative opioid use.40 Costs of inpatient hospitalizations, outpatient hospitalizations, and pharmaceuticals were consistently lower among patients who used postoperative opioids for fewer than 90 days, indicating the association between prolonged opioid use and an increased need for outpatient and inpatient care in the year after spine surgery. The relation between preoperative opioids and costs is consistent with previous literature.3,24,26,28,37,38

Study strengths include its large sample, the use of administrative data, and its design as a cohort study. Administrative databases reduce reliance on patient self-report for accuracy and allow for collection of comprehensive data for all patients. The cohort design allows for the demonstration of a temporal relation between exposures and outcomes.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: There are inherent limitations in using large administrative databases. The diagnosis of comorbid conditions or health outcomes are susceptible to billing code and data-input errors. Additionally, some clinical parameters, such as body mass index, could not be included in the study, as the information is not captured in the ICES databases. Since ODB data were consistently available only for individuals older than 65 years, they may not be generalizable to younger populations. Similarly, ODB data do not capture drugs obtained with private insurance, paid for out of pocket, or those obtained without prescription or through illicit means; in a publicly funded system, it is expected that this would not constitute an important confounder. Opioid prescriptions filled are not equivalent to opioids consumed, as prescribed opioids may remain unused or not used as directed. In addition, some patients may have been receiving preoperative or postoperative opioids for pain conditions other than those related to their spine surgery, and the complexity of each type of surgery or complications of surgery were not specifically accounted for. The need for subsequent spine surgery during the year after index surgery also, unsurprisingly, necessitated more prolonged opioid use. Finally, as the current study is observational, the identified associations cannot be presumed to be causal.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Opioid use before lumbar spine surgery was a strong risk factor for long-term postoperative opioid use, and duration of use was associated with increased resource utilization and costs. Strategic preoperative risk stratification and patient preparation, incorporating the factors determined in this study to be associated with prolonged opioid use, may inform optimal pharmacologic and nonpharmacologic pain management in at-risk patients, resulting in reduced resource utilization and cost. The results of this study will form a baseline for future investigations examining the impact of opioid reduction protocols and opioid stewardship programs, which are becoming increasingly more widely adopted.
